instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the inversion accuracy of water quality parameters and how far can this metric go in the study?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the inversion accuracy of water quality parameters in the related study is the coefficient of determination (R-2), root mean squared error (RMSE), and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE). These metrics provide a comprehensive assessment of the accuracy of the inversion results.

The R-2 value measures the proportion of the variance in the water quality parameter that can be explained by the model. It ranges from 0 to 1, with a higher value indicating a better fit between the predicted and observed values.

The RMSE represents the average difference between the predicted and observed values, providing a measure of the overall error in the inversion results. It is expressed in the same unit as the water quality parameter being measured.

The MAPE measures the average percentage difference between the predicted and observed values, indicating the relative error in the inversion results. It is expressed as a percentage, with a lower value indicating a higher accuracy.

These metrics together provide a comprehensive evaluation of the inversion accuracy of water quality parameters.
